Updated: 11:18 PM EDT Oct 3, 2024 INTO RUTHERFORD AND BUNCOMBE COUNTIES TO HELP THOUSANDS OF WORKERS ARE SPREAD THROUGHOUT OUR REGION, FOCUSED ON BRINGING POWER BACK AND CLEANING UP AFTER HELENE STANLEY SPENT THE AFTERNOON WITH THE GREENVILLE COUNTY CLEANUP CREW, AND HE JOINS US LIVE WITH THE DETAILS. NATE. NIGEL. CAROL. THAT CREW SAYS THEY COULD BE HERE UNTIL HALLOWEEN, HAULING TENS OF THOUSANDS OF POUNDS OF TREE DEBRIS EVERY DAY. A SOUND THAT WILL SOON BE FAMILIAR FOR MANY IN THE UPSTATE. AS CLEANUP CONTINUES FROM HURRICANE HELENE. IT’S A DIFFERENT SOUND THAN THE ONE HEARD BY JIM FERGUSON’S FAMILY FRIDAY MORNING. WE ALL HEARD IT, FELT IT WHEN THE TREE FELL OVER AND HIT THE HOUSE. I’M STANDING NEXT TO ONE OF THE MASSIVE TRUCKS THAT IS HAULING AWAY TREE DEBRIS HERE IN GREENVILLE COUNTY, AND WITH THE YARD LIKE THIS HAVING POSSIBLY THOUSANDS OF POUNDS OF TREE DEBRIS THAT COULD MAKE A STREET LIKE THIS LIKELY A MULTI-DAY JOB LIKE BY NEXT WEEK YOU’LL HAVE ENOUGH TRUCKS HERE THAT A NEIGHBORHOOD LIKE THIS WILL GET PICKED UP IN, LIKE A DAY OR TWO DAYS. ROBBIE ROCHE, A CONTRACTOR HELPING WITH PICKUP, SAYS HELENE’S DAMAGE WAS HISTORIC, WITH ALL THE STORMS I’VE BEEN DOING, WHICH I’VE BEEN DOING FOR ABOUT 20 YEARS, PROBABLY BEEN TO AT LEAST 35 OF THEM, 36 OF THEM. THIS WAS A LOT OF DEVASTATION, A LOT OF BRUSH, A LOT OF TREES DOWN. AND NOW FOR THE FERGUSON’S. THE SOUND OF FALLING BRANCHES IS A SIGH OF RELIEF. IT’S GREAT TO SEE IT OUT OF HERE JUST BECAUSE IT’S ONE STEP BACK TOWARDS NORMALCY. WE CAN’T START TO REBUILD IT UNTIL IT’S ALL OUT OF HERE. THE LORD WAS WATCHING OUT FOR US ON THAT AND YOU KNOW, AGAIN, WE’RE JUST IT’S NOT A GREAT SITUATION, BUT WE’RE GRATEFUL. AND A REMINDER, THIS IS A FREE SERVICE FOR GREENVILLE COUNTY RESIDENTS. ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS COLLECT THAT TREE DEBRIS, PUT IT ON THE SIDE OF YOUR ROAD, SAVE ROOM FOR THOSE WORK VEHICLES, AND DON’T INCLUDE TRASH BAGS OR OTHER TRASH IN THAT PILE. Updated: 11:18 PM EDT Oct 3, 2024 Nate Stanley Reporter The noise from heavy machinery and construction vehicles will soon be familiar to many in the upstate as clean-up continues after Hurricane Helene. It's a different sound than the one heard by Jim Ferguson's family Friday morning."We all heard it, felt it when the tree fell over and hit the house," he saidOn Thursday, a massive truck came through his neighborhood to clean the thousands of pounds of debris off of his yard. It's a free service that started this week by Greenville County, completely free to residents. According to the county, you can put your tree debris, without other trash or bags, along the side of your road, not blocking traffic, and a crew will come to pick it up. Assistant City Manager Hesha Gamble says it could take weeks to get to every home because of the extensive damage after Hurricane Helene.Robert Roche, a contractor helping with pick up, says Helene's damage was historic."With all the storms I've been to and been doing for about 20 years, probably been to at least 35, 36, this was a lot of devastation, a lot of brush, trees down," he said. "By next week, you'll have enough trucks that a neighborhood like this will get picked up in like a day or two."Now, for the Fergusons, the sound of falling branches is a sigh of relief."It's great to see it out of here. Just because it's one step back towards normalcy, we can't start to rebuild until it's all out," Jim Ferguson said. "The Lord was watching out for us on that, and, you know, again, we're just — it's not a great situation, but we're grateful."
